subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: Mr. Grahn, In your message below, I think you missed my point.  The predicate to my argument was a contrapositive: If we wrote QS phonetically...  I m using
messageBody:
Mr. Grahn,

In your message below, I think you missed my point. The predicate to my argument was a contrapositive: "If we wrote QS phonetically..." I'm using a reductio ad absurdum argument. Your analysis simply shows that we do not write QS phonetically, and that this is a good thing. If we assign IPA values to QS glyphs, then we are obliged to write phonetically, and my predicate would no longer be a contrapositive, and the result would be an "absurdum."

So, your analysis, while interesting, ends up making my point rather than refuting it.

Greg Weidman

----- Original Message ----

From: Anthony Grahn <othermale@...>

To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com

Sent: Friday, November 2, 2007 8:22:02 AM

Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear



--- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, Gregory Weidman <delrayva@.. .>

>

> The thing is: what if he and I were trying to communicate in QS?

> Ifwe wrote QS phonetically, I expect we would completely fail at

> communication. His writing would be as incomprehensible to me as

> his speech. However, with a more regularized spelling,

> written communication between North Carolina and New Zealand

> becomes possible again.

>



But the QS inconsistent- spelling- issue is not a problem in practice

and does not results in unreadability between accents. True, in theory

it seems like it might but in practice virtually all words come out

spelled the same. Those very few that don't will differ only slightly

and can be very easily inferred. To demonstrate this I have just run

the Drake example in the QM though my senior parser and got this result.


--SNIP--

Mr. Grahn,

In your message below, I think you missed my point.  The predicate to my argument was a contrapositive: "If we wrote QS phonetically..."  I'm using a reductio ad absurdum argument.  Your analysis simply shows that we do not write QS phonetically, and that this is a good thing.  If we assign IPA values to QS glyphs, then we are obliged to write phonetically, and my predicate would no longer be a contrapositive, and the result would be an "absurdum."  

So, your analysis, while interesting, ends up making my point rather than refuting it.

Greg Weidman

----- Original Message ----

From: Anthony Grahn <othermale@...>

To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com

Sent: Friday, November 2, 2007 8:22:02 AM

Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear



                              --- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, Gregory Weidman <delrayva@.. .> 

 > 

 > The thing is: what if he and I were trying to communicate in QS?

 > Ifwe wrote QS phonetically, I expect we would completely fail at

 > communication.  His writing would be as incomprehensible to me as

 > his speech.  However, with a more regularized spelling,

 > written communication between North Carolina and New Zealand

 > becomes possible again. 

 > 

 

 But the QS inconsistent- spelling- issue is not a problem in practice

 and does not results in unreadability between accents. True, in theory

 it seems like it might but in practice virtually all words come out

 spelled the same. Those very few that don't will differ only slightly

 and can be very easily inferred. To demonstrate this I have just run

 the Drake example in the QM though my senior parser and got this result.
